commander.name: Major-General Douglas Neil Wimberley
commander.previous_service: Led division through El Alamein victory, nicknamed 'Tartan Tam'

tanks.note: Infantry division - no organic tanks. Valentine tanks from attached armoured brigade for operations.

artillery.note: Full divisional artillery allocation. New 17-pounder AT guns deployed.

soft_skin_vehicles.note: Standard British infantry division motor transport allocation

supply_logistics.supply_status: GOOD - Part of Montgomery's supply buildup for Mareth assault. Supply lines from Tripoli (captured 23 Jan). Division in supporting role for failed frontal assault, then redeployed after NZ Left Hook success.
notes: Montgomery quadrupled 8th Army strength at Mareth (Feb 26 - Mar 18)
Division supplied from Tripoli port
Frontal assault consumed heavy ammunition
Redeployed after Mareth breakthrough

weather_environment.terrain_type: Mareth Line - Wadi Zigzaoug anti-tank ditch, fortified defensive positions, minefields. Coastal sector of Mareth defenses.
notes: Mareth Line heavily fortified
Wadi Zigzaoug anti-tank ditch key obstacle
Extensive minefields
Coastal sector terrain

subordinate_units.note: Battalions: 2nd Seaforth Highlanders, 5th Seaforth Highlanders, 5th Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders
Conducted probing attacks March 16-19. Battalions: 5th Black Watch, 1st Gordon Highlanders, 5/7th Gordon Highlanders
Battalions: 1st Black Watch, 7th Argyll & Sutherland Highlanders, 7th Black Watch

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry division in supporting role for Mareth Line assault. 153 Brigade conducted probing attacks. Two battalions (5th Camerons, 5th Seaforth) sent to support 50th Division's failed frontal assault at Wadi Zigzaoug. Heavy casualties before withdrawal 24 March.
special_capabilities: Veteran Highland division - continuous combat since El Alamein
known_issues: Frontal assault at Mareth failed - heavy casualties
Two battalions pinned down at Wadi Zigzaoug under tremendous fire
Attack called off - NZ Left Hook succeeded instead

major_battles: Battle of Medenine (6 March 1943) - defensive victory against Rommel
Battle of Mareth Line (16-24 March 1943): Probing attacks by 153 Brigade, heavy casualties supporting 50th Division frontal assault
notes: Division supported failed frontal assault at Mareth Line
153 Brigade probing attacks (16-19 March) found minefield gaps
50th Division led main frontal assault (20 March) - failed with heavy casualties
51st sent 5th Camerons and 5th Seaforth to support 50th at Wadi Zigzaoug
Battalions pinned down under tremendous fire, heavy losses
Withdrawn under smoke cover 0300hrs 24 March
Frontal assault called off 24 March - NZ Left Hook succeeded instead
Montgomery's Mareth strategy: frontal attack + Left Hook outflanking

source: WebSearch: 51st Highland Division Mareth Line March 1943
Wikipedia - Battle of the Mareth Line
known_gaps: Equipment allocations estimated from standard establishment
notes: Q1 1943: Division at MARETH LINE (Southern Tunisia)
Major operations: Medenine defensive (6 March), Mareth assault (16-24 March)
Commander: Major-General Douglas Wimberley ('Tartan Tam')
Role: Supporting (not main assault) - 50th Division led frontal attack
Casualties: Heavy losses at Wadi Zigzaoug (exact numbers not documented)
Tier 2 classification due to estimated equipment and missing casualty figures
Used 1942-Q4 baseline with Mareth 1943-Q1 delta changes

known_gaps: Equipment numbers estimated from standard division establishment
